childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1981-1993

The crackle of a Speak & Spell. The satisfying thunk of an Atari 2600 cartridge sliding into place. The neon glow of a Trapper Keeper folder that screamed 'this is who I am.' Your childhood had a particular weight to it—cassette tapes you had to rewind with a pencil, rotary phones where you'd lose your place dialing, TVs where you were the remote control.

You were the first. The eldest Millennials, the ones born the same year MTV launched and Reagan took a bullet. Everyone who came after you in your generation—the kids born in '85, '90, '95—they don't know what it was like to be the prototype. You were the beta testers for everything that came next.

Your living room had wood paneling and shag carpet. Your kitchen had avocado-green appliances leftover from the seventies. You watched Smurfs and He-Man on Saturday mornings, eating Count Chocula from a bowl you'd use every week until it cracked. You had a Big Wheel that left black marks on the driveway. You had Rainbow Brite sheets and a Cabbage Patch Kid with adoption papers your mom filled out.

At five, you watched the Challenger explode on live television. Your teacher wheeled the TV into the classroom because Christa McAuliffe was supposed to be inspiring—a teacher in space. Then the white plume split in two, and adults started crying, and nobody knew what to say. You learned something that day about promises and their limits.

Friday nights were Pizza Hut with the red plastic cups and the jukebox nobody used. Saturday afternoons were the mall—Waldenbooks, Spencer's Gifts, the arcade where Ms. Pac-Man ate your quarters. Sunday mornings were cartoons until your parents woke up, then church or brunch or yard work. Life had a rhythm. Life had edges. You knew where you were.

At eight, the Berlin Wall fell, and your parents watched the news with tears in their eyes. You didn't fully understand, but you understood that the world was changing, that something your parents had feared your whole life was suddenly over. You were old enough to sense the weight, young enough to assume that things would only get better from here.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Millennials

You're the original Millennial. Not the ones who ruined brunch or killed napkins or whatever the latest accusation is—you're from the first year of the cohort, the leading edge, the ones who broke the trail. When they talk about Millennials, they're often picturing someone born in 1990. That's not you. You're a different animal.

You were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} on September 11, 2001—{{GRADE_AT_911}}. A sophomore or junior in college, maybe working your first real job. You watched the towers fall in real time—not in a classroom like the younger Millennials, but in a dorm room or an apartment or a break room. You were old enough to understand immediately what it meant. Old enough to enlist. Old enough to be drafted, if drafts still happened. The friends you graduated high school with shipped out to Afghanistan and Iraq. Some didn't come back. The before and after of that day split your childhood in two.

Your generation spans 1981 to 1996—roughly 72 million Americans. You're the largest living generation, though Gen Z is gaining. You were raised on a steady diet of 'you can be anything' and 'follow your dreams' and 'you're special.' Then you graduated into the dot-com crash. Then the Great Recession. Then a pandemic. The dreams turned out to have fine print.

The 2008 financial crisis hit when you were {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}. Late twenties. Prime homebuying, career-building, family-starting years. You watched the job market evaporate. You watched housing prices crater after you'd already bought, or watched them crater while you couldn't afford to buy anyway. You learned that the system could collapse, would collapse, and that nobody was going to save you when it did.

You're the hinge generation—old enough to remember life before the internet, young enough to have grown up with it. You used card catalogs and then Google. You wrote papers longhand and then typed them on word processors and then emailed them. You're fluent in both worlds, which makes you adaptable but also occasionally homeless—too old for TikTok, too young for AARP.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

Raiders of the Lost Ark came out the year you were born—Harrison Ford in that fedora, melting Nazis, establishing a template for adventure that would define your childhood summers. MTV launched on August 1, 1981, and the first music video ever played was 'Video Killed the Radio Star.' You were three weeks old. The revolution was just beginning.

Your early TV memories are a specific cocktail of optimism and absurdity. The Smurfs in their mushroom village. He-Man declaring 'I have the power!' while you lifted whatever was nearby as your own sword. Voltron forming one giant robot from five smaller ones. ThunderCats. G.I. Joe. Transformers. Every cartoon existed to sell toys, and you didn't care because the toys were awesome.

At four, Michael Jackson released Thriller and became the biggest star on the planet. You learned the zombie dance. You probably had the red jacket or wanted it. At five, you watched Back to the Future and desperately wanted a DeLorean—or at least a hoverboard, which the movie promised you'd have by 2015. (Still waiting.)

By eight, you'd discovered Nintendo. Duck Hunt, Super Mario Bros., The Legend of Zelda. The Power Pad that never quite worked right. Blowing into cartridges like it was actual maintenance. Nintendo Power magazine with its maps and cheat codes felt like sacred knowledge. You knew the Konami code before you knew your multiplication tables.

Middle school was Nirvana and Pearl Jam and the sudden death of hair metal. Kurt Cobain played MTV Unplugged when you were twelve. He was dead by the time you were thirteen. Tupac and Biggie died when you were fifteen and sixteen. Grunge gave way to whatever came next—Britpop, third-wave ska, Alanis Morissette screaming 'You Oughta Know' on the radio while your mom changed the station.

High school was the era of Friends and Seinfeld and Must-See TV Thursday nights. You were fourteen when Pulp Fiction made nonlinear storytelling cool and teenagers started quoting Bible verses ironically. You were fifteen when Toy Story proved computers could make movies. You were seventeen when Titanic broke records and every girl you knew was crying over Leonardo DiCaprio. You'd seen so much death and disaster that a fictional boat sinking felt almost quaint.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The IBM PC launched the year you were born, which means personal computers have technically existed your entire life. But 'existed' and 'existed in your house' are different things. You grew up in the gap—after the technology arrived, before it was everywhere. Your childhood was still analog. Your adolescence was the bridge.

At three, you probably didn't notice when the Macintosh launched with its famous 1984 commercial. But by six or seven, there might have been an Apple IIe in your classroom, glowing green and beige, running Oregon Trail. You died of dysentery more times than you can count. You forded rivers when you should have caulked wagons. You learned that computers were both magical and frustrating.

Your first video game console was probably the Atari 2600 or the NES. Pitfall. Frogger. Pac-Man on a system that couldn't really handle Pac-Man. Then Nintendo arrived in 1985, and everything changed. Mario. Zelda. Metroid. Mega Man. You burned through weekends, argued over controllers, developed calluses on your thumbs that still haven't fully healed.

At ten, the World Wide Web was invented. You didn't know it yet. At fourteen, it went mainstream. At fifteen, you probably got your first email address—something on AOL or Hotmail that you hope nobody ever finds. The dial-up sound—that screech and static handshake—meant you were about to wait four minutes for a single image to load while your family couldn't use the phone.

AOL Instant Messenger launched when you were sixteen. You had a screen name you thought was clever, a buddy list organized by social hierarchy, and away messages that were basically poetry. The door-opening sound when your crush signed on. The agony of deciding whether to message first. The devastating three letters: 'brb.'

You were twenty-two when Facebook launched, twenty-six when the iPhone arrived. By then, you were a working adult. Smartphones were tools, not extensions of your identity. You adopted them, mastered them, but you remember life before them. You can read a map. You can be bored. You can sit in silence. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were five when the Challenger exploded. January 28, 1986. Seventy-three seconds after launch. You were probably watching in school because Christa McAuliffe was going to be the first teacher in space. The white trail forked, debris scattered, and adults who were supposed to have answers suddenly didn't. You were too young to fully understand death, old enough to understand that something terrible had happened. That stayed with you.

At five, Chernobyl melted down. At eight, the Berlin Wall fell—your parents watching CNN with tears in their eyes, sledgehammers on concrete, crowds pouring through. The Cold War was over. You were old enough to sense it mattered, young enough not to understand how much. For your parents, it was the end of an existential threat. For you, it was history homework.

The Gulf War happened when you were ten. The first war broadcast in real-time, green night-vision footage that looked like a video game. Scud missiles and smart bombs and 'surgical strikes.' You watched it over dinner. War as entertainment, war as television. You'd see that aesthetic again.

At twelve, the World Trade Center was bombed for the first time. You probably don't remember it much—six people died, and it seemed like an aberration. It was practice. At seventeen, Princess Diana died in a Paris tunnel, and you watched her funeral with 2.5 billion other people. At eighteen, Columbine happened. April 20, 1999. You were a senior in high school. The lockdown drills started. The clear backpacks. The question adults asked in lowered voices: 'Could it happen here?'

September 11, 2001 divided history—and your generation's identity was forged in that moment. You were twenty, old enough to enlist, old enough to understand immediately what it meant. (Your generational identity section already knows where you were.) The wars that followed—Afghanistan, Iraq—would last longer than you'd been alive when they started. Orange terror alerts became the new normal. Shoes off at airports, forever.

At twenty-seven, the financial system collapsed. You were building a career. Maybe you'd just bought a house. Maybe you'd just gotten married. The economy cratered at exactly the moment you were supposed to be establishing yourself. At {{AGE_AT_COVID}}, a pandemic shut down the world. You've lived through more 'unprecedented' events than most generations see in a lifetime. The word has lost its meaning.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You graduated college around {{COLLEGE_GRADUATION_YEAR}}, give or take. The worst job market since the Great Depression. Into the wreckage of the dot-com bust, in the shadow of 9/11. The job market was bruised but recovering. You found work, probably. Not the work you'd imagined, but work. You started climbing.

Then 2008 happened. You were twenty-seven. Not entry-level anymore—you'd been building for five or six years. Maybe you'd just gotten promoted. Maybe you'd just bought a house. Maybe you'd just gotten married and were thinking about kids. The economy collapsed at exactly the worst moment for you. Your generation has been called 'the unluckiest' because you got hit at peak vulnerability, twice.

Your parents' career path looked like this: get degree, get hired, work forty years, get pension, retire. Your path: get degree, get unpaid internship, get underpaid entry job, survive recession, rebuild, survive another recession, job-hop for raises, no pension, retirement is a fantasy, Social Security is a question mark. The rules changed mid-game.

You've watched the workplace transform around you. Cubicles became open offices. Open offices became 'collaborative spaces.' Offices became optional. Remote work became mandatory became optional again. Every change was sold as progress. Every change meant more work at the same pay.

The cruelest trick was making you believe it was your fault. Not networked enough. Not hustled enough. Not 'leaned in' enough. The truth is the game was rigged before you sat down to play. Wages decoupled from productivity in 1973. The social contract between employers and employees was shredded decades before you entered the workforce. You just got handed the bill.

You're in your peak earning years now, managing people probably. The Gen Z workers seem different—better boundaries, less tolerance for dysfunction, more willing to quit. Part of you admires it. Part of you resents it. They didn't have to learn that suffering was mandatory. Maybe it wasn't. Maybe you could have walked away too, and nobody told you.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when having a crush meant learning their locker combination? When getting their phone number was an achievement, and calling meant dialing seven digits (no area code back then) and hoping their dad didn't answer? When a passed note in class felt dangerous and thrilling and possibly illegal?

You learned to flirt through AIM away messages. Song lyrics as coded signals. The careful cultivation of a buddy profile. 'brb' when you weren't going anywhere—just waiting to see if they'd say something first. The heartbreak of watching their icon go idle. The hope when the door-opening sound meant they were back.

You're the bridge generation in dating. You met people the old-fashioned way first—at school, through friends, at jobs, in bars. Then Match.com arrived when you were in college, and online dating was something embarrassing you'd lie about. 'We met through friends.' By the time Tinder launched in 2012, you were already thirty-one, possibly married, possibly divorced, definitely confused about what these apps meant.

You've delayed marriage compared to your parents—not because you don't want partnership, but because the economics don't work. Average wedding: $30,000. Average house: laughable. Student loans: still paying. The life timeline your parents followed—married by 25, house by 28, kids by 30—wasn't available at any price you could afford. You're not immature. You're priced out.

Your friendships span decades and time zones. You've moved for college, for jobs, for rent. You maintain relationships through group texts that have been active for fifteen years, where nobody needs context because you all lived through it together. You know how to be close to people who are far away. You've had to learn.

You're at the age where you're attending more funerals. Parents, aunts, uncles, sometimes people your own age who weren't supposed to go yet. You've learned that relationships aren't infinite. That you should call your mom. That the friends who stuck around through all of it—the recessions, the moves, the marriages and divorces—those are the ones who matter.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three economic collapses before you turned thirty-five. The dot-com bust when you were twenty. The Great Recession when you were twenty-seven. COVID when you were thirty-nine. Each one taught you the same lesson: the floor can fall out at any moment, and nobody's coming to catch you.

Your parents saved because they remembered the Depression (or their parents did). Your grandparents spent because they trusted postwar abundance. You save because you've watched both strategies fail. Your relationship with money isn't rational—it's trauma response.

The numbers don't lie. A median home now costs six times the median income. Your parents bought houses for two years' salary. That ratio shift alone explains why the path they walked doesn't exist for you. They got pensions. You got 401(k)s and the advice to 'invest in index funds' while rent takes 40% of your paycheck.

You graduated with student debt that seemed manageable in 2003 and became a weight you're still carrying. The average was around $30,000 then—quaint by today's standards, but significant when entry-level jobs paid $30,000 and rent was rising faster than wages. Some of you are still paying. Some of you will be paying into your fifties.

The generational wealth transfer that was supposed to help you? It's going to healthcare for your aging parents. It's being spent on long-term care. It's evaporating in the gap between what Medicare covers and what assisted living costs. You're not inheriting a windfall. You're managing a decline.

You've redefined success by necessity. Homeownership feels less like a milestone and more like a fantasy. Retirement at 65 isn't the plan—it's a hope. You're not building wealth to pass down; you're trying not to become a burden to your kids, if you have them, if you can afford them. The math simply doesn't work the way it did for previous generations.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

You've adapted to so much that you've forgotten adaptation isn't the goal. You've optimized your resume, your LinkedIn, your morning routine, your meal prep. You treat systemic failures as personal productivity challenges. The housing crisis isn't a policy failure—it's a budgeting problem you can solve with better spreadsheets. Except you can't. The spreadsheet isn't broken. The system is.

Your cynicism, hard-earned as it is, limits you. You've been burned enough times that you expect the burn. You hedge your hopes. You don't trust optimism because optimism has betrayed you. But cynicism can become a self-fulfilling prophecy. If you assume nothing can change, you stop trying to change it. That's what they want.

You're conflict-averse in ways that cost you. You've been trained to be team players, to bring solutions not problems, to not rock the boat. You'll accept 'that's just how it is' as an explanation. You'll endure toxic workplaces because the job market is brutal and you need health insurance. You've mistaken accommodation for maturity.

The digital world feels like action, but it's often performance. You can post outrage on social media, but local elections—where policy actually changes—have dismal turnout. You can sign petitions, but city council meetings happen without you. The dopamine hit of engagement isn't the same as power. You know this. You do it anyway.

You compare yourself to the wrong benchmarks. You measure your success against your parents' lives at your age, forgetting that they had fundamentally different economic conditions. Then you measure yourself against Instagram versions of your peers, forgetting that Instagram is a highlight reel. You're winning a game that doesn't exist while losing the one that does.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you've internalized the narrative. The self-improvement industry thrives because it's easier to sell you a fix than to fix the system. You've spent so long optimizing yourself that you've forgotten to question why the optimization is necessary. The benchmarks keep moving. The targets keep shifting. At some point, you have to stop chasing and start asking who set the course.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2001-2011): You started this decade with September 11 and ended it climbing out of the Great Recession. In between: the dot-com hangover, two wars, the rise of social media, the first black president, and the collapse of everything you'd been told about how careers worked. You were supposed to be finding yourself. Instead, you were finding out how precarious the world actually was. You delayed milestones your parents hit by 25. Not because you weren't ready—because the math didn't work.

Your 30s (2011-2021): Recovery, finally, then COVID. You rebuilt your career from the recession wreckage. Maybe you got married, had kids, bought a house—the traditional markers, delayed but not abandoned. Social media matured while you were in your thirties, which means there's a comprehensive online record of your decade whether you want one or not. The pandemic hit in your last year of this decade, reshuffling everything you'd just stabilized.

Your 40s (2021-2031): You're in this decade now. Post-COVID, post-whatever-normal-used-to-mean. Your kids are in school or approaching it. Your parents are aging, needing more. You're sandwiched—responsible for generations above and below, managing careers and mortgages and healthcare decisions and college savings and retirement accounts that don't have enough in them. This is supposed to be your peak earning decade. Whether that's true depends on factors largely outside your control.

Your 50s (2031-2041): This will be your final career push—the decade to maximize whatever you can before the inevitable slowdown. Your kids will be launching. Your parents may be gone or need serious care. You'll be thinking about legacy, about what you've built, about whether it was enough. Retirement is a question mark. You're hoping Social Security survives. You're hoping your 401(k) survives. You're hoping you survive.

Your 60s and beyond (2041+): You'll be the oldest Millennials entering retirement age, assuming retirement still exists as a concept. The world will be unrecognizable—climate change will have reshaped where people live, AI will have reshaped what work means. You'll tell younger people about rotary phones and VHS tapes and a time before the internet. They won't believe you. You barely believe it yourself. But you've survived everything thrown at you so far. You'll figure this out too. You always do.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you. You're the leading edge of the 72 million Americans classified as Millennials—the largest living generation, at least for now. Gen Z is gaining.

Compared to Gen X (born 1965-1980): They got the same degrees, often from the same schools, but they got jobs that paid enough to buy houses in their twenties. They had pensions, or at least the tail end of pensions. They came of age in relative economic stability; you came of age in economic whiplash. When they were your age, houses cost three times the median income. Now it's six. The difference isn't work ethic—it's timing.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964): The wealth gap is almost comical. When Boomers were your age, they controlled 21% of national wealth. You control 7%. They bought their forever homes at 28 with a single income and a high school diploma—houses that cost about two years' salary. They lecture you about fiscal responsibility from properties that appreciated 400% while they slept. They had union jobs with benefits. You have gig economy 'flexibility' with no safety net. They're not bad people. They just don't understand that the world they navigated doesn't exist anymore.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You remember life before the internet. They don't. You still believe, somewhere deep down, that the system can be reformed. They assume it's broken and are building around it. You adapted to smartphones as adults; they were born into them. You have nostalgia for analog; they have no frame of reference. Neither of you has savings, but for different reasons.

Your life expectancy is 78-80 years—slightly lower than previous generations, thanks to rising 'deaths of despair.' Your generation has worse mental health outcomes than any before, which is framed as a personal failing rather than a rational response to irrational conditions.

But you've made the world better in ways that don't show up in economic statistics. You normalized therapy. You destigmatized mental health struggles. You pushed for marriage equality and began the long work of racial reckoning. You inherited a harder world and made it more inclusive. The economy is rigged against you, but the culture shifted because you showed up. You were the first Millennials, the prototype, the ones who figured out how to survive without a manual. That counts for something.
